questions.text: A 35-year-old male undergoing hernia surgery was administered succinylcholine. After administration of anesthesia, he developed muscle rigidity, elevated temperature, and increased etCO2 levels. What is the appropriate treatment for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dantrolene sodium

 

The clinical presentation described is characteristic of malignant hyperthermia, a genetic condition affecting the ryanodine receptor gene in muscles. It is triggered by exposure to succinylcholine or inhalational anesthetics. The pathophysiology involves:

 

  • Continuous muscle contraction due to calcium retention in muscle cells
  • Hypermetabolism leading to elevated temperature
  • Increased CO2 production causing elevated etCO2 levels

 

Dantrolene sodium is the specific antidote for malignant hyperthermia as it blocks calcium release from sarcoplasmic reticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diazepam: Incorrect as it is just a sedative and does not address the underlying pathophysiology of malignant hyperthermia

 

Option B. Midazolam: Incorrect as it is also just a sedative like diazepam and has no role in treating malignant hyperthermia

 

Option D. Adrenaline: Incorrect as it is primarily used in CPR and severe hypotension. It does not treat the underlying mechanism of malignant hyperthermia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dantrolene sodium is the specific treatment for malignant hyperthermia, a condition triggered by succinylcholine and inhalational anesthetics characterized by muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and increased etCO2.

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

 

The correct answer is Mutation of tRNA. A suppressor mutation, specifically a tRNA mutation, can reverse the effect of an earlier mutation that produced a premature stop codon. In this scenario, the tRNA undergoes a mutation that allows it to recognize the stop codon (UAA in this case) as if it were a normal codon (e.g., serine's codon UCA). This suppressor tRNA can then insert an amino acid at the site of the stop codon, allowing protein synthesis to continue. This compensates for the earlier mutation that would have led to a truncated, non-functional protein, thereby restoring the wild-type phenotype.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frameshift mutation of coding gene: This type of mutation typically disrupts the reading frame of the gene, leading to widespread changes in the amino acid sequence from the point of mutation onward. It usually results in a non-functional protein and does not suppress the effects of another mutation.

 

Option B. Addition of another normal gene: While adding a normal gene might help correct a phenotype by introducing a functional version of the gene, it does not qualify as a suppressor mutation. This option does not specifically address the reversal of a mutation at the molecular level in the same way as tRNA mutation does.

 

Option C. Deletion of the mutant gene: Deleting the mutant gene would remove the mutation but would not revert the phenotype to wild type by itself. It eliminates the gene's effect entirely rather than compensating for the mutation within the gene or another gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for brachial plexus block. After some time, the patient developed hypotension and cardiovascular collapse. What is the best treatment for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 20% Intralipid

 

In the case of hypotension and cardiovascular collapse following a bupivacaine brachial plexus block, the recommended treatment is intravenous lipid emulsion therapy (e.g., 20% Intralipid). This treatment is specifically targeted at reversing the toxic effects of bupivacaine, which is a lipophilic local anesthetic. The other options, while useful in various cardiovascular emergencies, are not the primary treatments for bupivacaine toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication used primarily for the treatment of certain types of serious arrhythmias. It's not typically used for the acute management of bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular collapse.

 

Option B. Epinephrine: This is a critical care drug used in the management of various life-threatening conditions, including anaphylaxis and cardiac arrest. It could be used in this scenario for its vasoconstrictive and positive inotropic effects, but it might not be the first choice due to the risk of exacerbating cardiac arrhythmias, which can be a complication of bupivacaine toxicity.

 

Option C. Dobutamine: This is a β1-selective vasoactive agent used primarily for the management of heart failure and cardiogenic shock. It increases cardiac output but would not be the first-line treatment for bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intralipid therapy is the recommended treatment for severe local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur with medications like bupivacaine. It acts by trapping lipophilic drugs like bupivacaine in an intravascular lipid emulsion, reducing their toxicity.

choices.text: Covers the active site on actin

questions.text: Which attribute accurately describes myosin within muscle fibers? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Exhibits ATPase activity

 

Explanation:

 

Myosin forms the thick filaments in muscle and possesses ATPase activity in its globular head region. The myosin head contains both an actin-binding site and a catalytic site that hydrolyzes ATP. This ATPase activity is essential for the power stroke during muscle contraction, as ATP hydrolysis provides the energy needed for the conformational change in the myosin head that generates force.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Component of thin filaments: Myosin constitutes the thick filaments, not the thin filaments. The thin filaments are composed of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin.
  • Option b. Covers the active site on actin: This is the function of tropomyosin, not myosin. Tropomyosin covers the myosin-binding sites on actin during muscle relaxation, and is displaced when calcium binds to troponin C.
  • Option d. Calcium-binding protein: Calcium binding is the function of troponin C, not myosin. Troponin C contains specific binding sites for calcium that initiate the contractile process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myosin's ATPase activity is fundamental to muscle contraction as it hydrolyzes ATP to generate the energy needed for the power stroke, which creates movement by changing the angle of the myosin head while attached to actin.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lienorenal ligament

 

The structure marked in the image is identified as the lienorenal ligament. The lienorenal ligament is a peritoneal ligament that connects the spleen to the left kidney. It is crucial because it contains important structures such as the splenic artery and vein.

 

In the provided image, you can see the vertebra centrally located, with the kidneys visible on each side. The spleen, which lies adjacent to the stomach, is connected to the kidney by the lienorenal ligament. The splenic artery, a branch of the celiac trunk, passes through this ligament.

 

During surgical procedures, especially when ligating the splenic artery, knowledge of this ligament's anatomy is essential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This ligament connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. It contains the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery. However, in the provided image, the marked structure does not represent this ligament.

 

Option C. Lesser omentum: The lesser omentum is a double layer of peritoneum extending from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the first part of the duodenum. It contains the portal triad (portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile duct). The marked structure in the image is not the lesser omentum.

 

Option D. Greater omentum: This is a large apron-like fold of visceral peritoneum that hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach. It covers the intestines but is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lienorenal ligament is a peritoneal structure connecting the spleen to the kidney and contains the splenic artery. This ligament is essential for surgeons to identify, especially during procedures involving the spleen or splenic artery.

choices.text: Junction of the superior vena cava (SVC) and left brachiocephalic vein
Junction of the left internal jugular and left subclavian vein

questions.text: Where does the thoracic duct enter the systemic circulation? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. Junction of the left internal jugular and left subclavian vein

 

 

Explanation:

 

The thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body, extending from the cisterna chyli in the upper abdomen to the root of the neck. After ascending through the posterior and superior mediastinum, the thoracic duct arches laterally at the level of the seventh cervical vertebra. It then descends in front of the first part of the left subclavian artery and finally terminates by opening into the angle of junction between the left subclavian and left internal jugular veins, effectively entering the venous system at this point.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Junction of the SVC and left brachiocephalic vein: The thoracic duct does not enter at this location. This junction is too far from the neck region where the thoracic duct actually terminates.

 

Option C. Directly into the coronary sinus: The coronary sinus is a venous structure located in the heart that drains cardiac veins. The thoracic duct has no direct connection to the coronary sinus.

 

Option D. Into the azygos vein: While the thoracic duct and azygos vein are both located in the posterior mediastinum, the thoracic duct does not empty into the azygos vein. The azygos vein drains into the superior vena cava.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The thoracic duct, which collects lymph from the entire body except the right upper quadrant, terminates by emptying into the venous system at the junction of the left subclavian and left internal jugular veins.

questions.text: Which nerve innervates the second branchial arch?(NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Facial nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is the nerve that innervates the second branchial arch. This is a fundamental relationship in embryological development where each pharyngeal (branchial) arch has its own specific nerve supply. The second branchial arch is also called the hyoid arch, and all muscles derived from this arch are innervated by the facial nerve, including the stapedius, stylohyoid, posterior belly of digastric, and muscles of facial expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a. Mandibular nerve - This is incorrect because the mandibular nerve (branch of trigeminal nerve, CN V3) innervates the first branchial (mandibular) arch, not the second. The first arch derivatives include muscles of mastication, mylohyoid, anterior belly of digastric, tensor tympani, and tensor veli palatini.

 

Option b. Maxillary nerve - This is incorrect because the maxillary nerve (branch of trigeminal nerve, CN V2) is purely sensory and does not innervate any branchial arch musculature. It provides sensory innervation to structures derived from the maxillary process of the first arch.

 

Option d. Vagus nerve - This is incorrect because the vagus nerve (CN X) innervates the fourth and sixth branchial arches through its branches - the superior laryngeal nerve innervates the fourth arch while the recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the sixth arch. It does not innervate the second arch.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Each branchial arch has a specific cranial nerve associated with it that innervates all muscles derived from that arch. The facial nerve (CN VII) specifically innervates all muscles derived from the second branchial arch, including the muscles of facial expression

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the Green marked structure in the image in anatomical position? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coccyx

 

The marked structure in the image is the ischial spine. In anatomical position, the ischial spine is located at the level of the coccyx. This is important in various medical procedures, including the pudendal nerve block, commonly used in obstetrics and gynecology. The ischial spine serves as a significant landmark for these procedures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L4: Incorrect. The L4 vertebra is located much higher in the vertebral column, around the lower back region, and is not associated with the ischial spine.

 

Option B. L4-L5: Incorrect. This option refers to the intervertebral disc space between L4 and L5, which is also in the lower back but not related to the pelvic region or ischial spine.

 

Option C. S3-S5: Incorrect. Although the ischial spine can be aligned with these sacral vertebrae in certain positions like lithotomy (during childbirth), but here the question is about anatomical position so this is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischial spine in anatomical position aligns with the coccyx, serving as an important landmark for various medical procedures.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint marked in the image: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saddle

 

  • The marked joint in the image is the incudo-malleolar joint, which is a type of saddle joint. This joint is located in the middle ear and involves the malleus and incus bones. The mnemonic "SBI" helps remember the types of joints in relation to the incus:
    • S for Saddle joint (incudo-malleolar joint)
    • B for Ball and socket joint (incudo-stapedial joint)
    • I for the Incus, positioned in front and behind the respective joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ball and socket: Incorrect. The ball and socket joint is found in the incudo-stapedial joint, not the incudo-malleolar joint.

 

Option C. Plane: Incorrect. The plane joint is not represented in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Option D. Gliding: Incorrect. Gliding joints are not present in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incudo-malleolar joint is a saddle joint, an important anatomical feature in the middle ear.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in an inner segment of the photoreceptor? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Disc 

 

Disc membranes are specifically located in the outer segment of the photoreceptor, not the inner segment. The inner segment contains most cellular organelles, including:

 

  • Mitochondria
  • Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
  • Golgi apparatus
  • Nucleus

 

The outer segment is characterized by the presence of disc membranes, which are crucial for phototransduction. 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Decreases affinity of O2 by increase in PCO2
Left shift of Hb-O2 dissociation curve
It is due to increased H+

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Bohr effect is NOT true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Left shift of Hb-O2 dissociation curve

 

Explanation:

 

The Bohr effect is characterized by a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, which decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen when blood pH decreases or PCO2 increases. This physiological phenomenon facilitates oxygen unloading in metabolically active tissues where CO2 production is high and pH is lower. The "BohR" effect (with the helpful mnemonic "R" for Right shift) occurs in peripheral tissues where oxygen release is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Decreases affinity of O2 by increase in PCO2 - This is a true statement. When PCO2 increases, it forms carbonic acid, lowering pH and causing hemoglobin to release oxygen more readily (decreased affinity), which is the Bohr effect.
  • Option c. It is due to increased H+ - This is correct. The Bohr effect occurs because deoxygenated hemoglobin binds H+ more actively than oxygenated hemoglobin. The increased H+ concentration (lower pH) is the primary mechanism behind the Bohr effect.
  • Option d. All are true - Since option b is incorrect, not all statements are true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bohr effect represents a physiological adaptation that facilitates oxygen unloading in tissues by causing a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve in response to increased PCO2 and decreased pH, while the opposite effect (left shift) occurs in the lungs, known as the Haldane effect.

questions.text: A person who at the time of commission of the offense was of unsound mind, is exempt if he didn't know the nature of the act or its consequences. This rule is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McNaughton rule

 

The McNaughton rule, also known as the legal test or right-wrong test, is the standard used in India to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if, at the time of the commission of the offense, they were suffering from a mental disorder that rendered them incapable of understanding the nature of their act or knowing that it was wrong. This rule emphasizes the individual's ability to understand the act, rather than their ability to control their behavior.

 

The rule is codified in Indian law under Section 84 Indian Penal Code (IPC) (Now, 22 BNS) and has been the primary standard for assessing the criminal liability of mentally ill offenders in India. If a person can understand that their actions are wrong, they are held responsible; otherwise, they are not.

 

Additional Information

 

Various rules related to the criminal responsibility of mentally ill individuals:

 

  • McNaughten Rule: This is a legal test that focuses on whether the person knew right from wrong at the time of the offense. This is also referenced in Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
  • Irresistible Impulse Test: Indicates that a person is not responsible if they acted on an uncontrollable impulse despite knowing the act was wrong.
  • Durham Rule: A person is not criminally responsible if the unlawful act was the product of a mental disease or defect.
  • Currens Rule: States that a person is not responsible if they lacked the capacity to conform to the requirements of the law.
  • American Law of Institute Test: A person is not responsible if they lacked:
    • Adequate capacity to appreciate the criminality of their conduct due to a mental disease or defect (cognitive insanity).
    • Adequate capacity to conform their conduct to the requirements of law (volitional insanity).
  • Doctrine of Partial Responsibility: This implies that while a person may be responsible, their mental illness is considered as a mitigating factor, potentially leading to reduced culpability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Durham's rule: This rule states that an individual is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act was the product of mental disease or defect. It focuses on the presence of a mental disease or defect as the cause of the unlawful act, rather than the individual's understanding of the nature of the act.

 

Option C. Currens rule: This rule states that an individual is not criminally responsible if they lacked the capacity to conform their conduct to the requirements of the law due to mental illness. It emphasizes the individual's ability to conform their behavior to legal standards.

 

Option D. Irresistible impulse test: This test states that an individual is not criminally responsible if, due to mental illness, they were unable to control their actions or resist the impulse to commit the act, even if they understood the nature of the act and that it was wrong.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, the McNaughton rule is used to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if they were unable to understand the nature of their act or know that it was wrong due to their mental condition.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. Fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hard exudate, Diabetes mellitus

 

The given image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with discrete margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetic macular edema.

 

 

COTTON WOOL SPOT vs HARD EXUDATE

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy

 

 

Hypertensive retinopathy

 

 

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) – Fundoscopy reveals massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins. Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft exudate, Hypertension: Soft exudates, also known as cotton wool spots, are whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins.

 

They occur around infarcted areas and result from swelling of nerve fiber layer axons.

 

Associated with hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

 

Option C. Flame-shaped hemorrhages, Hypertension: Flame-shaped hemorrhages are superficial retinal hemorrhages that occur due to disruption of the capillaries in the retinal nerve fiber layer.

 

They are seen in diabetic retinopathy, non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion, traumatic retinopathy, Eale's disease, hypertensive retinopathy, and anemic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterized by massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins.

 

Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

Soft exudates can be seen in CRVO but are not the primary finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hard exudates are characteristic findings in diabetic retinopathy, indicating chronic localized edema and composed of leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages. They present as small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with distinct margins in the retina.

questions.text: Pneumoconiosis associated with exposure to cotton dust is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Byssinosis.

 

Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease," is a type of pneumoconiosis specifically associated with exposure to cotton dust. It is an occupational lung disease that typically affects workers in the textile industry, including those involved in spinning, weaving, and processing cotton. The inhalation of cotton dust can cause the airways to become constricted, leading to symptoms such as chest tightness, coughing, and wheezing, particularly at the start of the workweek, which is sometimes referred to as "Monday fever."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bagassosis: This is a pneumoconiosis caused by exposure to bagasse, the fibrous material left over after sugarcane or sorghum stalks are crushed to extract their juice. It is commonly seen in workers in the sugar industry.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Also known as "black lung disease," this condition is caused by the inhalation of coal dust. It primarily affects coal miners and results in the accumulation of carbon particles in the lungs.

 

Option D. Silicosis: Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of silica dust, which is commonly found in industries like cement, glass manufacturing, and stone cutting. It leads to inflammation and scarring in the lungs.

 

Note –

 

Asbestosis: Caused by exposure to asbestos dust, asbestosis is a serious condition that leads to lung fibrosis. It is prevalent among workers in the cement industry and is particularly noted in shipyard workers due to the historical use of asbestos in ship construction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of Pneumoconiosis:

questions.text: Which of the following statements about exanthema subitum is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Associated with Slapped Cheek Appearance

 

Explanation:

  • Exanthema subitum, also called Sixth Disease or Roseola infantum, is caused by Human Herpes Virus-6 (HHV-6). 
  • The disease is characterized by abrupt onset of high-grade fever, followed by appearance of the rash after the fever subsides. 
  • The rash resembles measles but is not described as having a "slapped cheek appearance." Nagayama spots are associated with this condition, but not a slapped cheek appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Known as Sixth Disease - This is correct. 

 

  • Exanthema subitum is indeed known as the Sixth Disease in the classification of childhood exanthems.

 

Option B. Known as Roseola - This is correct. 

 

  • HHV-6 causes "roseola infantum" where "roseola" means rose-like and "infantum" refers to its common occurrence in infants.

 

Option C. Caused by Herpes Virus - This is correct. 

 

  • Exanthema subitum is caused by Human Herpes Virus-6 (HHV-6), which is a member of the herpesvirus family.

 

Option D. Associated with Slapped Cheek Appearance - This is incorrect. 

 

  • The "slapped cheek appearance" is characteristic of Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) caused by Parvovirus B19, not exanthema subitum. 

 

 

  • Parvovirus B19 infection causes a maculopapular rash that evolves into a reticulated lacy exanthem

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Exanthema subitum (Sixth Disease/Roseola infantum) is caused by HHV-6, characterized by abrupt high fever followed by a rash after fever subsides, while the "slapped cheek appearance" is characteristic of Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) caused by Parvovirus B19.

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ichthyosis vulgaris

 

  • The clinical image depicts a newborn covered in a shiny membrane that resembles parchment, suggesting a disorder on the autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum (Lamellar ichthyosis, Bathing suit ichthyosis, Harlequin ichthyosis)
  • Icthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutation in the Filaggrin gene (FLG).
  • Ichthyosis vulgaris is unlikely because it does not manifest at birth.

 

Fig: Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis, Shedding of collodion membranes after 1 week.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamellar ichthyosis

  • Description: Infants with lamellar ichthyosis are often born with a collodion membrane, which sheds after a few weeks. The skin then becomes darkly pigmented with large, plate-like scales. Ectropion and eclabium can also be present.

 

Option C. Bathing suit ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a rare type of ichthyosis where the scaling is restricted to the trunk, sparing the extremities and face. It's called "bathing suit" due to the distribution pattern resembling the area covered by a bathing suit.

 

Option D. Harlequin ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a severe form of ichthyosis, where infants are born with very thick skin that forms large, diamond-shaped plates separated by deep fissures as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Features like ectropion, eclabium, and respiratory difficulties are common.

 

Autosomal Recessive Congenital Ichthyosis (ARCI) includes the following:

 

  • Lamellar ichthyosis (LI)
  • Bathing suit ichthyosis (BSI)
  • Harlequin ichthyosis (HI)
  • Congenital Ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE)
  • Self-limiting congenital ichthyisis (SLCI)
  • Collodion baby

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an unlikely diagnosis in a new-born presenting with a collodion membrane, ectropion, eclabium, and extensive skin lesions, given that ichthyosis vulgaris is typically a milder form and less likely to present with such severe symptoms at birth.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 65 Page no 65.4, 65.6-65.10

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8161842/

questions.text: A child presents with mental retardation, bone pain, and inability to walk. On fundoscopy examination, a cherry red spot is seen. There is no organomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

 

Tay-Sachs disease. The given clinical scenario, along with the fundoscopy image showing a macular cherry-red spot, indicates that the most likely diagnosis is Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease: Niemann-Pick disease is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it often presents with hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), which is not mentioned in the case. The cherry-red spot is not a typical feature of Niemann-Pick disease.

 

Option C. Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis I), autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs. Enzyme deficient is α-L-Iduronidase. Presents usually at 6-24 months with clouded cornea, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, and skeletal dysplasia. Glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge are the other features. The condition is generally fatal.

 

Option D. Gaucher’s Disease presents with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance. Mental Retardation is not seen.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Age 6 months – 5 years
Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes
No need for long term antiepileptics

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about febrile seizure?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 54% recurrence

 

Febrile seizures are convulsions brought on by a fever in infants or small children. They are relatively common and typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years. The main features of febrile seizures include:

 

  • Age 6 months – 5 years: This is the typical age range for febrile seizures, making this statement true.
  • Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes: Simple febrile seizures are brief, usually lasting less than 15 minutes. This statement is also true.
  • No need for long term antiepileptic: In the case of simple febrile seizures, long-term antiepileptic treatment is generally not necessary. This statement is true as well.

 

The statement "54% recurrence" is not true. The recurrence rate for febrile seizures is significantly lower. While there is a risk of recurrence, it is not as high as 54%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febrile seizures typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years, last less than 15 minutes, and do not require long-term antiepileptic treatment. The recurrence rate is much lower than 54%.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, and hematuria. The mother tells you that the baby also suffered from bloody diarrhea a few days back. Which is likely microorganism to be isolated from the stool sample? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. coli O157:H7

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) based on the triad of:

 

  • Hematuria
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • History of bloody diarrhea

 

E. coli O157:H7, also known as Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) or Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC), is the most common causative organism of HUS, particularly in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shigella flexneri

 

  • Incorrect because while it can cause bloody diarrhea, it is more commonly associated with reactive arthritis rather than HUS.
  • Does not typically cause the combination of hematuria and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Salmonella enteritis

 

  • Incorrect as it is primarily associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease.
  • Not typically associated with HUS.

 

Option D. Aeromonas

 

  • Incorrect as it typically causes simple diarrhea without the complications of HUS.
  • Does not produce Shiga toxin, which is responsible for HUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E. coli O157:H7 is the most common cause of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome in children, typically presenting with bloody diarrhea followed by the triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever, muscle pain, and jaundice after working in flooded fields. Laboratory tests reveal a positive microscopic agglutination test. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Leptospirosis

 

The clinical presentation and exposure history are classic for leptospirosis. The key diagnostic findings include:

 

  • Occupational exposure (farmer working in flooded fields)
  • Classic triad of fever, muscle pain, and jaundice
  • Positive microscopic agglutination test (MAT), which is the gold standard diagnostic test for leptospirosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Diagnosed using different serological tests, not MAT.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium infection: Does not typically present with acute jaundice and is not diagnosed using MAT. 

 

Option C. Bacillus infection: Not associated with exposure to flooded fields or diagnosed using MAT.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is the gold standard diagnostic test for leptospirosis, which typically occurs after exposure to contaminated water or soil.

questions.text: Which of the following is more common in Anorexia Nervosa when compared to Bulimia Nervosa? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Amenorrhea

 

Explanation:

 

Amenorrhea is more frequently associated with anorexia nervosa, primarily due to the effects of significant caloric restriction and weight loss on the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Starvation leads to a drop in GnRH, which lowers FSH and LH levels, resulting in decreased estrogen and subsequent menstrual irregularities or absence. While amenorrhea was once a diagnostic criterion in DSM-IV and ICD-10, it is no longer required in DSM-5 or ICD-11—but it remains a common clinical feature.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Dental Caries: More common in bulimia nervosa due to frequent self-induced vomiting. The repeated exposure of teeth to stomach acid leads to enamel erosion and caries—less typical in the restricting subtype of anorexia.
  • Option B. Antisocial Behavior: Neither disorder is primarily associated with antisocial traits. However, bulimia nervosa has stronger links to impulsivity and emotion dysregulation. In contrast, anorexia nervosa is often marked by control, rigidity, and perfectionism.
  • Option C. Craving for Food: Intense food cravings, particularly those leading to binge eating, are more characteristic of bulimia nervosa. While people with anorexia may think obsessively about food, they usually resist these urges rather than act on them.

 

Educational Objective:


Amenorrhea is a hallmark physiological consequence of the nutritional and hormonal imbalances seen in anorexia nervosa. Recognizing this and other subtle distinctions between anorexia and bulimia can help guide both diagnosis and management.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with a history of dysphagia, regurgitation, foul breath, and cough. Bilateral lung crepitations are noted on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker's Diverticulum

 

Explanation:


Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum that occurs when pharyngeal mucosa herniates through Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle). This condition typically affects elderly individuals, particularly those over 60 years. The clinical presentation in this case is classic: dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis (foul breath), and cough with evidence of aspiration pneumonia (bilateral lung crepitations).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schatzki Ring: This is a circumferential narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction that typically causes intermittent dysphagia for solids only. It would not explain the regurgitation, halitosis, or respiratory symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus: This refers to diffuse esophageal spasm with non-peristaltic contractions of the esophagus. While it can cause dysphagia and chest pain, it doesn't lead to regurgitation, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: This is characterized by a triad of dysphagia, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. It predominantly affects middle-aged women, not elderly men, and doesn't typically cause regurgitation, foul breath, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, and respiratory complications due to aspiration in an elderly patient strongly points to Zenker's diverticulum. Food collects in the pouch and can later be regurgitated, causing aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

 

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to an elevated level of bilirubin in the blood that has not been processed by the liver into its conjugated form. Gilbert syndrome is a common genetic disorder that causes mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This condition results from reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: (Mnemonic: DR BHATIA)

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This condition causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a defect in the liver's ability to secrete conjugated bilirubin into the bile ducts, leading to its buildup in the liver.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: Similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome also leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a benign condition that results from a defect in the hepatic storage and excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

 

Option C. Biliary atresia: This condition also results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a serious liver disease in infants where the bile ducts become inflamed and blocked, preventing bile from draining from the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme responsible for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text: Structure lies in the floor of inferior horn of lateral ventricle all except (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tail of caudate nucleus

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn, not the floor.

 

Roof of Inferior horn - Tapetum (part of the corpus callosum), medial part of tail of the Caudate Nucleus and Striate Terminus

 

Floor of Inferior horn – Fimbria, hippocampus, collateral sulcus and collateral eminence.

 

Other Options:

 

The inferior horn of the lateral ventricle is a part of the brain located in the temporal lobe. Structures found in the floor of the inferior horn include the hippocampus, fimbria, and collateral eminence.

 

Option A. Collateral eminence: This is a ridge in the floor of the inferior horn formed by the collateral sulcus.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: A crucial structure for memory conversion, located in the floor of the inferior horn.

 

Option C. Fimbria: A bundle of nerve fibers on the hippocampus that forms part of the floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle, not in the floor.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arachnoid mater

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure you will pierce while performing a lumbar puncture.

 

Layers pierced while performing lumbar puncture/spinal anesthesia (subarachnoid space) from outside to inside are:

 

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater

 

Upon piercing the arachnoid mater, you enter the subarachnoid space (lumbar cistern), where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected during a lumbar puncture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligamentum flavum: The ligamentum flavum is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is pierced before the dura mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option B. Dura mater: The dura mater is a tough outer meningeal layer that is pierced before the arachnoid mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option D. Pia mater: The pia mater is the innermost meningeal layer that directly covers the spinal cord. It is not pierced during a lumbar puncture.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure pierced before entering the lumbar cistern during a lumbar puncture.
